newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan OKs "floating hotels" for China workers.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan OKs "floating hotels" for China workers.

text.p: Taiwan plans to legalise "floating hotels" just off the island's east and south coasts, housing sailors from China awaiting jobs from Taiwanese fishing vessels, a newspaper reported on Sunday.
The plan followed repeated complaints by fishing companies and an increase in drownings among fishing workers from China during typhoons, the daily China Times said.
The boathouses or "floating hotels", converted from old fishing boats to provide shelter for job-seeking Chinese sailors, have existed illegally in Taiwan's territorial waters since 1992.

Taiwan's Council of Agriculture was expected to make a formal announcement next week to legalise the boathouses in an attempt to keep watch over the sailors, the paper quoted council chairman Chiu Mau-ying as saying.
Chiu told the paper Taiwan's cabinet had approved the plan.
Under the plan, Taiwan would set up anchorage zones near the island's various fishing ports, which would allow better regulation of the boathouses by port police and fishery officials.
Fishing companies or agents could ferry the Chinese sailors from outside Taiwan's territorial waters to the boathouses in the anchorage zones.
Taiwan's Nationalist government, which lost a civil war to China's communists in 1949, bans direct contacts with China and does not allow mainland people to work for Taiwan companies.
But because of an acute shortage of sailors and fishing workers, authorities often turn a blind eye to fishing companies which recruit mainland Chinese.
The newspaper said as many as 1,000 mainland sailors stay at some 18 "floating hotels" outside Suao Harbour in northeastern Taiwan, making living conditions difficult.
At least 10 mainland sailors have drowned during typhoons since 1994.
